author: Sara Castellanos
title: When the Hacker Threatening Business Operations Is a Well-Armed Nation State
text:
0 COMMENTS An LED-illuminated wireless router in Philadelphia Photo: Associated Press 
The joint alert by U.S. and U.K. intelligence agencies warning that Russian cyberattackers are targeting critical internet infrastructure to spy on Western companies reflects the growing threat that individual companies face from well-armed nation-states.
“If you were doing all the right things to be cyber secure, I’m not going to say you’re penetration-proof, especially from a nation state,” said Peter Zornio, chief technology officer of Emerson Automation Solutions.
Monday’s joint alert by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the U.K.’s National Cyber Security Centre said Russian state-sponsored hackers had penetrated devices and software programs world-wide in order to steal corporate secrets and conduct espionage.
Industrial conglomerate Emerson Electric Co. invests heavily in cybersecurity to help thwart attacks on customers in the critical infrastructure space, such as power, chemicals and natural gas companies, Mr. Zornio said.
One of Emerson’s main concerns is that attackers could take over a critical control system. One security technique to help protect against that involves using “data diodes” which allows one-way transfers of data throughout a network and physically prevents data from coming into the network, Mr. Zornio said.
“The real danger is that you take over a refinery and cause an explosion or take over a power plant and shut it down or damage it irreparably,” Mr. Zornio said.
Employees are often the weakest link and training the workforce about how to identify phishing emails is important, he said.
The company has boosted its investment in cybersecurity technologies, trainings, staff and certifications by about 50% annually for the past three or four years, Mr. Zornio said. Investing in cybersecurity is crucial, but it won’t guarantee that a company will never be attacked.
Still, being more secure than a competitor could prove to be extremely beneficial, he said. “If you’ve got an alarm system, your door is locked and you’ve got a German Shepherd barking loudly, (the attackers) are going to go to your neighbor,” he said.
Suzette Kent, federal chief information officer, said corporate CIOs should “take these alerts seriously.” She recommends a so-called pulse check with the corporate security team and corporate leadership.
“As CIO, you want to provide some assurance that your team is able to ingest and respond to these types of alerts with minimal disruption,” said Ms. Kent, formerly principal at Ernst & Young, who was appointed federal CIO earlier this year .
“You also want to level-set with leadership when these alerts are critical, their potential impact on core services, and of course, to escalate quickly when you need additional resources to mitigate those risks,” she continued.
